The council is required to take account of regional variations, cost-effectiveness, social and economic impacts and other intergovernmental mechanisms. Another desirable cooperative federal-state feature is that the council secretariat is expected to consist of only a small staff with reliance being placed on state expertise to avoid duplication.

I am hopeful, but not confident, that the intention of the legislation and the mechanisms contained in it will, in time, prove sufficient to take account of state interests, as expressed in the original agreement. If that proves to be the case, then I would hope also—again I cannot pretend I am confident—that the Western Australian government, recognising it owes its first duty to the people of that state, in due course might join the scheme proposed under the bill. It would only then be a truly national and cooperative scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) is in a very difficult position on the National Environment Protection Council Bill. I am glad to see he supports it, but his party colleagues in Western Australia do not. I did not find his defence of them at all convincing. I understand that the objections that the Western Australian government has made to the National Environment Protection Council and its related policy include that the Western Australian government wants a review of the national greenhouse response strategy involving the United Nations Convention on Climate Change, which most countries of the world have now supported. Similarly, it wants to stop Australian ratification of the UN Convention on Biological Diversity, which, again, a large number of countries have now ratified, and it is not persuaded that national strategies on conservation matters should be finalised until the Commonwealth Environment Protection Authority has demonstrated that nationalisation of environmental issues brings increased efficiency on both environmental and economic matters.

PARA.TAB: How could a national strategy not bring improved efficiency? There is constant complaint from the business sector about inconsistencies in environmental policies between the Commonwealth and the various states. Since the intention of the National Environment Protection Council is to try to reduce those differences, I would have thought it was very obvious that efficiency would be increased.

I am glad that the opposition is supporting this bill for a very good reason and that every other state and territory government has decided to support it, but it really does reflect very badly on the Western Australian government that its own extremist position on the environment prevents it from supporting what is an entirely reasonable bill. The minister who introduced this bill in the Senate, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), absolutely rightly said:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Environment Protection Council Bill is an important landmark in the history of environment protection in Australia. It marks the commitment of the Commonwealth and the states and territories to work cooperatively to develop national environment protection measures. These measures aim to give all Australians the benefit of equivalent environmental protection and to ensure that investment decisions by business are not distorted by variations in environmental standards between Australian jurisdictions.

That surely says it all. That is the purpose of the council. It outlines its tasks and those tasks are entirely in the interests both of the environment and of the business community because it will reduce inconsistencies in the way environmental policies are made between the states. Development like this has been crying out to be made for some years. I notice that the member for Tangney said that it was not before time that something of this kind was introduced. I agree with him, but that makes it all the more sad that his own party in Western Australia is not involved in supporting the bill.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Tangney outlined the purposes, composition, functions and mode of operation of the council so well that there is really no point in my repeating what he said. So all I really need to do is emphasise that this bill is a response to the difficulty that the Commonwealth has in developing environmental policy in the national interest in the situation where it has no direct environmental power. That is, of course, because the constitution was prepared in an age when people were not substantially aware of environmental matters.

The Commonwealth has been able to achieve some standardisation of environmental policy by using other powers given to it: the external affairs power, in particular, and the trade and commerce power to some extent. But those are indirect influences so it is very important to build up as strongly as possible on a cooperative basis the relationships between the Commonwealth government and the state governments to ensure environmental protection and a proper balance between environmental protection and the needs of the economy and human society.

That is the purpose of this bill. It will establish a council made up of ministers from the Commonwealth and state governments. It will be serviced by a very small secretariat. It will make policies relating to a whole series of issues which many Australians are very concerned about: issues such as air quality, water quality, noise, site contamination, problems associated with hazardous wastes, motor vehicle emissions and reuse and recycling of materials.

All of those are issues that a high proportion of Australians are really concerned about, and I am quite sure there would be overwhelming support in the community for this bill because people want those issues to be taken more seriously. They want firm clear guidelines set for them, and the establishment of this council will provide the institutional framework within which that can happen more effectively.

The activities of the council, as the member for Tangney repeated a couple of times, require it to take account of cost effectiveness in deciding what measures to adopt. They require it also to look at the social and economic impact as well as the environmental impact of decisions that are made and obligations under existing international treaties. The council is empowered to set standards, goals, guidelines or protocols, instruments with different levels of strength and power, and that gives it quite a degree of flexibility.

I was pleased to note also that the bill encourages the council to seek public comment on what it proposes to do. That is something that will be welcomed because there is great interest in environmental matters in the community.

In summary, I strongly support this bill. I welcome the fact that the government is presenting it and I strongly support the efforts of the government to achieve comprehensiveness in membership. I hope that very quickly the Western Australian government will agree to join the council as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we were looking at this National Environment Protection Council Bill in 1990 and 1991 I remember doing a lot of work with the then shadow environment minister, Fred Chaney, who was the honourable member for Pearce in Western Australia. It seems to me that the whole process has been a long time in its gestation.

PARA.TAB: Many of the things that we were talking about in those days are now in the bill. Some of the things that were raised at the time from the government's side, on which we counselled that some caution was required, have certainly been taken on board, as have concerns from other members of the broader community. I am pleased to see that the government has been responsive in that respect.

The bill establishes the National Environment Protection Council, pursuant to the intergovernmental agreement on the environment, signed by the Commonwealth government and all the state and territory governments and the president of the Local Government Association in 1992. It establishes the council's functions and powers. It is interesting that at the special Premiers Conference in Brisbane in October 1990, the question of implementation of a national environmental strategy involving the Commonwealth and states was discussed. Long overdue in my opinion, it was then acknowledged that all levels of government have different roles in the environment protection and management fields and that any agreement should outline those respective roles and responsibilities. The intergovernmental agreement on the environment, the IGAE, was signed subsequently on 1 May 1992. That agreement is contained in the schedule to this bill.

There are a number of mechanisms outlined in that IGAE agreement. The IGAE sought a cooperative national approach to the environment; a better definition of the roles of respective governments; a reduction in the number of disputes between the Commonwealth and states and territories on environmental issues; greater certainty of government and business decision making; and better environmental protection. The IGAE also acknowledged the role of the respective tiers of government, and it recognised the trans-boundary nature of environmental concerns. In other words, in colloquial terms, when a bug goes from Victoria to New South Wales it does not recognise that the Murray might actually be a state boundary. It is quite right that we recognise the national nature of those things and, of course, the IGAE also recognises the need for ecologically sustainable development and the importance of sustainable land use.

The IGAE set out a number of broad principles of environmental policy: the precautionary principle, being broadly the careful consideration of the possibility of serious or irrevocable environmental damage; the preservation of inter-generational equity, in other words, the maintenance of the environment for future generations; conservation of biological diversity and ecological integrity; and improved market mechanisms encompassing the consideration of environmental costs, the principle of polluter pays and the establishment of cost-effective environmental goals.

The IGAE went on to talk about setting up an environmental protection authority—although this bill, in fact, sets up the protection council. It talked about the need for national environmental protection measures which might cover things such as ambient air quality, ambient marine and freshwater quality, noise related issues, guidelines for the assessment of site contamination, and environmental impacts associated with hazardous wastes, motor vehicle emissions, and the re-use and recycling of materials.

One of the concerns mentioned by previous speakers is that, whilst this move is supported by the federal government, the opposition and the state governments around the country, there have been concerns articulated by the West Australian government. I understand that in May this year the Western Australian minister for the environment, the Hon. Kevin Minson, issued a paper entitled `The Proposed National Environment Protection Council (NEPC)—analysis and criticism of the concept by the government of Western Australia.'

The paper argued a number of things. In particular, it said that the NEPC was unnecessary because it would require state parliaments to forfeit their powers to disallow regulations, whilst allowing the Commonwealth to retain such powers in the area of pollution standards; that uniform national pollution standards are impractical because of the wide variety of Australian environments and their uses; that the NEPC would reduce competitiveness by introducing another layer of centralised regulation; and also that the NEPC would tie up resources of pollution control agencies.

It seems to me that a response to a number of those concerns can be more than adequately dealt with. When making national environment protection measures, the NEPC will be required to take into account regional variations, and that is obviously commonsense. The NEPC will aim not for strict uniformity but rather for a consistent approach to environmental protection. The NEPC will be administratively efficient, I would hope. Certainly it is not large. Its secretariat has nine people or fewer and it will be sharing with the states expertise regarding environmental problems to make sure that it avoids duplication. I would have to say that avoidance of duplication is going to be a very critical test of this particular body.

It also seems that states with higher standards than those set by the NEPC will have the flexibility to retain those standards. Therefore there will be some pressure from the other states to get those states which have got minimum standards to raise their standards so that Australia as a nation—and I think all too often we do not think sufficiently about Australia as a nation—will be able to compete effectively in the wider world.

In the bill itself there are a number of objectives set out specifically. I think one should remind the committee of the two major objectives of the act. One is for people to enjoy the benefit of equivalent protection from air, water or soil pollution and from noise wherever they live in Australia. The other objective is that decisions of the business community are not distorted and markets are not fragmented by variations between participating jurisdictions in relation to the adoption or implementation of major environment protection measures.

It seems to me that one of the difficulties for businesses operating in this country, and not only in the area of the environment but also in the areas of labelling regulations, safety regulations and many different areas, is that if you want to be a national company you have to comply with so many different rules. They are on a different basis in different states. There is a cost factor involved. There is a time factor involved.

If we are talking about establishing some decent domestic critical mass for many of our companies and for the products they produce as a springboard to going overseas, which we all acknowledge is very important, then we ought to be looking to minimise some of those costs and to having consistent standards. I think this is a move in the right direction.

Of course, we have already heard the membership of the council. There is the federal minister and also ministers from each of the states and from the Northern Territory. There is the need for a two-thirds majority before things can be adopted. It seems to me that that is a very substantial majority and should protect the interests of the smaller states which might feel threatened. It is also interesting to note that not only will we have regular reports to the parliament but also that after five years the whole process is going to be reviewed.

I have already mentioned some of the areas in which the council will take action. There is one important variation to the general theme of ambient air and water and so on. That concerns noise and emission standards relating to the design, construction and technical characteristics of new and in-service motor vehicles. Those standards that the council might be involved in have to be made in agreement with and in conjunction with the National Road Transport Commission and they must be determined in accordance with the National Road Transport Commission Act. So there are a number of safeguards in this legislation to make sure that we do not have the environment impinging unrealistically in areas that have wider implications.

The national environment protection measures must each comprise one or more of the following. There must be a national environment protection standard, a protection goal, a protection guideline or protection protocol. The process is set out fairly comprehensively to make sure that central government does not run rampant in this particular area.

All that really remains for me to say is that what we have is a recognition by all Australian governments that environmental issues do not just recognise state borders. I am sorry that the Western Australian government is not able to come to the same view. I think a small national body to deal with those international aspects of environment and interstate issues and coordination is a very sensible move. There is clearly an intent to try to avoid duplication.

There is clearly an intent to try to avoid duplication and I think the bureaucracy will have a heavy responsibility in that respect. I think there is not only a recognition of the importance of protecting the environment for today and for future generations but also an acknowledgment that economic factors must be realistically catered for.

We do not need a repetition, for example, of the Coronation Hill situation; we do not need to argue the rights and wrongs all over again of that particular decision. What happened there quite clearly was that political decisions got in the way of the economic and environmental decisions in the final analysis. Hopefully, the sort of legislation we are talking about this morning will get around those sorts of difficulties and will give industry some consistency in what it is doing.

In many areas of Australia, we tend to miss out as a nation because of fragmented rules and regulations, which often conflict, as I said before. I think this will go some way to help those concerns. The cost of not doing things in a coordinated way is enormous, in terms of both dollars and quality of life. It seems to me that the proof of the pudding is in the eating—in other words, in the way this legislation actually operates on a day-to-day basis. It is a sensible piece of legislation and it is deserving of the support of this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This National Environment Protection Council Bill clearly reflects the lack of constitutional power that the Commonwealth has in environmental matters. Clearly, under the constitution the Commonwealth has no express power over the environment. In the past, the Commonwealth has intervened in environment matters in two ways: firstly, through cooperation with the states through agreements; and, secondly, through other heads of power—for example, corporations power or the external affairs power.

PARA.TAB: In terms of environmental protection generally, this has led to cooperation with the states with a lowest common denominator approach, with the states only agreeing to the lesser standards, sometimes to be embodied in uniform legislation. Unfortunately, the history of uniform legislation in Australia shows that very soon it becomes `un-uniform'. One of the states changes it and the whole impact of that uniformity is lost.

This legislation gets us away from this lowest common denominator approach by setting what are called national environment protection measures, NEPMs. Other speakers have set out the areas in which these measures are to be enforced. Nevertheless, I am going to talk about enforcement. The enforcement of these measures is to be achieved by appropriate mechanisms such as state and Commonwealth environmental protection authorities. This comes about by virtue of clause 17 of schedule 5 of the original agreement between the Commonwealth and the states. The schedule also obliges the states and the Commonwealth to draft legislation allowing the NEPA to establish NEPMs and to ensure enforcement of the NEPMs in the states.

I want to talk about enforcement, because I think this is one of the crucial problems. To some extent, this bill is the last chance for Commonwealth-state cooperation in the area of the environment. As I have already stated, the Commonwealth has very limited powers in relation to the environment. However, this is not widely recognised in the community.

There is no doubt that the public also sees the environment and its preservation as a major concern. To digress, it is very clear that young people in Australia see the environment as important. Any surveys of young people show that they are very concerned about the environment. In schools in my electorate, young people say that their first concern in the general political area is the environment. This is not going to change. There is a great expectation from the Australian people that we should deliver in the area of the environment.

We also know this from market research carried out by ANOP, the federal Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and the ESD secretariat in 1991. This market research shows that a clear majority of Australians believe that the Commonwealth should have power to set national standards and enforce them: 73 per cent believe that the Commonwealth should set uniform standards for air and water pollution, 68 per cent believe we should protect plant and animal species, and 62 per cent believe we should set uniform standards for soil and land degradation. Only a minority of those surveyed, between 25 and 35 per cent on these issues, believe that such matters should be left to the states.

Coming through the survey is a belief that the Commonwealth has more power than it really has in the area of environment protection. In my electorate these matters are a little bit more confused because of the presence of two World Heritage areas. Because the Commonwealth can act in World Heritage areas, there is an expectation that the Commonwealth can act in other areas. Quite often in Cairns something happens outside the World Heritage areas and I am called upon to do something, as is the federal Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), when quite clearly the Commonwealth has no constitutional power to act. This perception of extensive power, especially under World Heritage, has been promoted by the politicians of the right, not by the Labor government and not by the conservation movement. On 25 August 1987 the then Premier of Queensland, Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, said in relation to the World Heritage listing of the Far North Queensland wet tropics:

SPEECH.PARA: They—
that is, the Commonwealth, which is always `they'—
have set out a blueprint, a plan to take over the whole of North Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you worry about that.
—Yes, that's right. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: They will run it, administer it in every way—tourism, primary industry, business.

We still get some of these absurd pronouncements today. We still hear people say that the wet tropics locks up all the land in the area, as if the Commonwealth has some power over land management through the wet tropics.

PARA.TAB: It is very interesting to digress a little bit and note that the same thing is being said today about native title. People are saying that native title will lock up all of Cape York Peninsula. It is very interesting that there is some analogy there. The same sort of nonsense that was peddled in the 1980s about the wet tropics is now being peddled about native title.

Nevertheless, there is a general perception in the community that the Commonwealth does have power in relation to environmental areas. If this cooperative approach does not work here, then the Commonwealth will have to consider other measures. This makes the attitude of governments like the Western Australian government vital to the success of this sort of approach.

Speaking following the original intergovernmental agreement on the environment in April 1992, which led to this legislation, the former minister, the member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), said the agreement had been very hard to negotiate, with some states reluctant to support it. This was before Western Australia pulled out. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: If it doesn't work, in my view we'll just have to go for some constitutional change in the environment.

I agree with that statement by the member for Canberra. I believe that if this bill does not work—and that means if Western Australia does not get on board and the states do not cooperate—then there will have to be some response by the Commonwealth. Bearing in mind the degree of support in the community for constitutional change, I would not bet on it not getting through. Those people on the other side of the House who support states rights should be getting behind this bill in a big way, because it is probably the last chance for states rights in the environmental area.

PARA.TAB: There is a difficulty legally in relation to the enforcement of intergovernmental agreements, and the High Court has been quite reluctant in the past to see such agreements as enforceable. I set out the terms of the bill earlier and it certainly sets out a very strong regime for enforcement. If we are looking at further areas of constitutional reform, this is a significant problem and we need to talk about it. We do not want this process to break down. If we want the states to cooperate, we will have to provide a greater level of opportunity for the enforcement of agreements. If we do not, I guess the next step will be that the Commonwealth will legislate to give itself power over the environment.

The High Court has been very reluctant in the past to enforce such interstate agreements. The court says that they are not enforceable and that they give rise to political obligations rather than legal obligations. It is worth quoting Mr Justice McTiernan in the case of South Australia v. the Commonwealth in 1961. That case relates to the attempt to get some agreement for uniformity in legislation dealing with rail gauges in Australia. That is something that the rights of the state got in the way of as well. When talking about this sort of agreement Mr Justice McTiernan said:

SPEECH.PARA: It does not provide legal rights or obligations. It works as a matter of governmental policy. The promises on either side are of a political nature, and both parties would understand at the time the agreements were made, that this was the true nature of the promises. Their performance necessarily requires executive and further parliamentary action. It is a matter for the discretion of respective governments to take such action if and when they see fit to do so. It is not contemplated by either agreement that its performance could ever be made the subject of judicial order.

That of course relates to that matter raised in 1961. In relation to Mr Justice McTiernan's last sentence, I think it is true to say that this legislation attempts to give an agreement between the Commonwealth and the states some sort of enforceability, and that is the key to this legislation's working.

PARA.TAB: If this legislation does not work, the first thing the Commonwealth should do is have a look at the position that the High Court takes to see whether we can get through, with the cooperation of the states, some sort of constitutional amendment that gives those sorts of agreements enforceability. If we cannot get to that position, I think the Commonwealth will have to start thinking about public opinion in relation to the environment and how it is going to exercise its proper power. From time to time we cop criticism from the public for our actions on the environment but we really do not have the power to do anything. In the long run that is probably going to be an untenable political situation for any Commonwealth government.

As I said, it is of concern that the Western Australian government has not come on board in terms of this legislation. If the public want national legislation, that means national legislation and it does not exclude Western Australia. Of course that does not mean that the people of Western Australia do not expect the Commonwealth government and the Western Australian government to endorse environmental standards.

I have been reading an excellent book by Phillip Toyne, called The Reluctant Nation, in which he very clearly sets out the problems that have occurred in the past with respect to Commonwealth-state relations on the environment. He also says that those arrangements have probably, in some ways, been successful through the use of the external affairs power but that they have sometimes failed the public's expectation in relation to the environment. Phillip Toyne is very critical of the approach of this bill. He does not hold out a lot of optimism for this agreement and this bill to be successful. Again, I guess one of the problems is the enforceability of the rights.

Nevertheless, I totally support this legislation because we have got to go through this step. We have got to give the states a chance to come to the party and we have got to give the states a chance to fulfil their obligations. Phillip Toyne very clearly sets out the difficulties and the limitations that have occurred in our approach in the past. To be fair to him, he would say that some of the problems have been of a political nature rather than of a constitutional nature. In another part of the book Mr Toyne quotes the following passage:

SPEECH.PARA: We give the impression to the world at large that we see the defence, in an absolute sense of some extreme version of States' Rights, as being important itself . . . as we come to a centenary of Federation (it is important) that Governments of every persuasion, in a very open way, are prepared to address some of these shibboleths, some of these sacred cows that both sides of politics have in their own ways held to be sacred for so long and that have held back the progress of the Australian people.

Now that is not some mad left-winger from the Labor Party. That is a quotation about the Liberal Party from the then Premier of New South Wales, Nick Greiner. So Nick Greiner recognises that states rights are often getting in the way of national objectives. That is what Phillip Toyne is talking about in this book and that is what I hope this legislation recognises.

PARA.TAB: I endorse the appointment of Mr Toyne as Deputy Secretary to the Commonwealth Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. That is an excellent appointment. It is an appointment that the department itself has made. I think that Mr Toyne will be an excellent addition to the Commonwealth bureaucracy, if I might use that word, because of his very broad experience both as a lawyer working in the Northern Territory for Aboriginal rights and also as someone who is part of the conservation movement. The Commonwealth department will be very much enhanced by his appointment.

In the very short time that I have left, I will talk about a local issue which highlights some of these problems about Commonwealth-state relations. That is the question of the development at Hinchinbrook, which has been the cause of some controversy, certainly in the part of the world that I come from, and it obviously has some sort of national significance. Again, I would like to take this opportunity of congratulating not only the former Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, the member for Canberra, but also the present Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, because I think he has handled these very difficult issues of Commonwealth-state relations in the area of the environment with great aplomb.

In terms of Hinchinbrook, I put on the record that I totally support his approach in relation to the matter—that is, that it is very important in relation to the Great Barrier Reef to uphold World Heritage values. Senator Faulkner has insisted on a baseline study on the effect the proposed development on Hinchinbrook would have on the Hinchinbrook Channel and development at Cardwell; and I certainly support that action. Obviously when the Commonwealth has the information in relation to the baseline study, then the Commonwealth can make a proper assessment about the effect the marina part of the development, at least, would have on the Great Barrier Reef, one of the World Heritage areas. I totally support Senator Faulkner in that stand.

But the situation is very illustrative of the crazy situation we have in this country in relation to the environment and Commonwealth-state relations. I am not even saying in this speech whether the Commonwealth should do something about it, because we have got to see the end of the baseline study. However, the Commonwealth can do something about the channel but it cannot do anything about what is on the land. It has no power to assess what is on the land. If the proverbial man from Mars came to Australia and looked at that situation, he would go away thinking we were crazy because somehow the Commonwealth has the power for water but not for land. That is the situation that we have got in this country today because of so-called states rights.

I think the public demands a better approach. I am not suggesting the Hinchinbrook development should not go ahead or that it should go ahead—I am not saying that in this contribution to the debate. What I am saying is that, if we are to have proper decision making in this country, it should not be of that nature—that the state government makes an announcement in relation to a development. The Commonwealth role is very clear: the Commonwealth has an obligation to look after World Heritage areas. That is why Senator Faulkner has fulfilled his duties to perfection because he has fulfilled the Commonwealth's obligation. Yet to all intents and purposes, the development has been given the go-ahead.

It seems to me that, if we do not refine our arrangements for Commonwealth-state cooperation so that we do not get that sort of situation in the future, we are going to have to look towards some sort of constitutional change. If conservative forces line up against that they may find themselves on the losing side. I emphasise the overwhelming public support in the community for preservation of the environment. That is something that people see as very important.

In conclusion, I totally support this legislation. I implore honourable members on the other side to talk to the Court government, saying that this is the last chance for cooperation in the area of the environment. Otherwise there is no other option but that the powers they have will be taken away at some stage. I implore them to ask the Court government to get on board. I congratulate the coalition on its attitude to this legislation and I totally support the legislation before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Environment Protection Council Bill establishes the National Environment Protection Council, which aims to introduce a cooperative national approach to the environment. The Commonwealth currently does not have any express power in relation to the environment, but the establishment of this council will help all tiers of government in Australia to develop a national environmental strategy.

PARA.TAB: Most environment issues, for example water or air pollution, do not discriminate against state boundaries so it makes sense to have a national council such as this. The Premiers Conference, in 1990, raised the issue of implementation of a national environment strategy to help governments avoid conflicts on environmental decision making. The three tiers of government signed the intergovernmental agreement on the environment in 1992.

The coalition initially had concerns with the National Environment Protection Council, as we feared it would mean another layer of bureaucracy and further centralisation of power in Canberra. However, the council will be made up of a representative of each state as well as a federal representative and it will have a secretariat with a maximum of nine staff. The council will also be required to take into account regional variations. From past rhetoric, however, regional representation from the federal government does not imbue me with confidence.

When established, the National Environment Protection Council will be responsible for national environment protection measures which will look at air and water quality, noise, hazardous waste, site contamination, motor vehicle emissions and recycling.

One of the aims of the intergovernmental agreement on the environment, which I mentioned earlier, was the protection of the environment for future generations. The issue of environmental sustainability cannot be treated lightly nor can it be dealt with by platitudes and rhetoric. However, at times the federal government treats the environment debate in just this way. Going on the experience of my own electorate, I would say that many times the government is more intent on national publicity campaigns which attempt to capture the imagination of peak lobby groups, rather than on-the-ground work with our environmental problems.

I will list a few of the issues which are electorate specific. The first is the World Heritage listing of Lake Eyre. That has been a long-running issue, yet not until very recent weeks have the local people even been consulted. A meeting took place in Birdsville last year. I understand that the then federal minister (Mrs Kelly) actually flew over Birdsville but could not land to spend even half an hour with the quite big gathering there. Those people felt at the time and still feel that they are fighting for their very livelihoods—in that region, that means their lives.

Another issue is the management of nuclear waste sites throughout Australia such as the one in my electorate. The decision was taken, despite all the rhetoric. I was quite happy with the process—the way the public consultation was going—but then those sites were announced in the Adelaide Advertiser without any consultation with any of the people on the ground. A few weeks later, because of a court decision in New South Wales, we have the convenient dumping—admittedly of low-level nuclear waste—in Woomera, because that is a convenient site. Once again, this occurred with very little consultation. Once again, it is said that it will be there for only a short period; it is certainly not a permanent site. But it is indicative of the importance of balancing the centralist power with a respect for people in the regions.

Over the years I have had some involvement with the environmental movement. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd), spoke of Phillip Toyne. A few years ago I worked with Phillip on the land care issue. Generally speaking, it was a reasonably harmonious relationship. Obviously, there are tensions. From my position, coming from the land, it was difficult to reconcile the bigger picture issues of taxation on the land, the economic issues, with the need and the respect that the overwhelming number within my regional community had for the issue of land care and the importance of doing something about it. But we got through that period, and I acknowledge Phillip Toyne's role in it, along with that of Rick Farley, who addressed, with the government of the day, a very important issue.

To this day, the great unfinished business is the matter of the economic policies which put so much pressure on our land. I call it our great national schizophrenia, in the sense that we want all the good things from the land in the way that we tax it, in the way we distribute the wealth, but we are not prepared to acknowledge that the overwhelming number of people who are working the land basically are battling to make decent social welfare payments. Even before an operator on the land—who after all has the land at heart—can get a living wage, he pays something like 30 or 40 per cent of his costs straight into the national Treasury.

So I come back to my theme of the national schizophrenia of land care. For all the wonderful power that we think we might have in this place as legislators—many of us lawyers who have an understanding of the law—legislators and lawyers do not actually plant trees unless they physically go out and do it. So people with the encouragement and the incentive to go out and do practical things are needed. That is something I would implore the federal government to always consider: the practical reality of getting as many people as possible on side through practical incentives to improve this environment of ours.

Another issue I want to discuss in this matter of the environment—and I want to try to come from a practical point of view—is the rabbit. It is a fairly mundane subject to many, I suppose. There are estimated to be about 300 million rabbits in Australia. The cost to agriculture from rabbit damage in Australia is about $90 million. I do not think we have to talk long to convince people about the effect on soil erosion and the general effect on the regeneration of native vegetation. In this one simple example I want to try to explain to particularly the urban population that if land care is one of our most profound environmental issues, and if the rabbit is one of the most destructive components of it, surely it is reasonable that in our policies we give far greater consideration to this issue. As one leading environmental magazine commented:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems reasonable to ask why we are not controlling—
our rabbits—
more effectively. The rabbits are winning; we and the ecosystems are losing. Why? Because of the priorities for spending money. The 1990s is the decade of tree planting. Our Prime Minister—
of the day—
announced that we would plant one billion trees before the year 2000. The PM and his advisers are demonstrably ignorant of the problems of the semi-arid 70% of this continent.

That comment is from someone outside my philosophy or certainly outside my expertise. That person is making the general comment that we really need to focus on much more of the practical in our dealing with the environment.

PARA.TAB: Mention was made of the rail industry. I would be the first to agree that it was sheer folly the way we organised our rail industry in the last century. I think we have moved on a little bit since the rail industry. We do have telephones; we do have faxes; we do have a whole range of what I think most of us would agree is a remarkable array of technology for communicating. There would be those who would say we might even be able to do away with this place and simply communicate by modern technology. So things have changed. There is no excuse for not offering reasonable communication from Commonwealth to state to local.

In the defence of the Western Australian government—and I am not here as an apologist for those in the Western Australian government; they are quite capable of defending themselves—I do recall a comment by Richard Court, the Premier, in the native title discussion where he was, in his opinion, deliberately sidelined for political purposes. I want to bring in Phillip Toyne's point about the way politics always has its hand there; however heavy or however hidden or whatever, the fundamental of politics is always there. Richard Court felt very strongly that in the native title issue he was deliberately sidelined. He felt that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and those from the government were deliberately setting him up to play the political game. I will let that rest there but I think Phillip Toyne might have a point about the way that politics is played and the way that politics has come in to this whole environmental debate.

To conclude, no-one is going to deny that we have a responsibility to future generations for the environment. No responsible government—national, state or local—will deny that there is a very strong responsibility to the centuries ahead. We have made quite remarkable progress in many ways. We have the tools at hand to do a lot better than we have. We are suffering from too much rhetoric and too much appealing to lobby groups rather than appealing to the general population and offering incentives where we can get on top of a lot of environmental issues in a much more practical way. We have this issue of World Heritage listing which is going to be played, I have no doubt, for every inch of political mileage that the government can get out of it. We have the Murray-Darling system which is crying out for a cooperative settlement of the issue.

It was pleasing the other day to see the South Australian state government and the Prime Minister put money into the tin to clean up the Patawalonga. It was very pleasing. It is possible to have sensible Commonwealth-state resolutions of environmental issues. If there is a willingness to tackle these issues in goodwill, it is not necessary, as some from the government would say, to abolish the states and have this heavy-handed constitutional power. If the Commonwealth insists on playing politics for every inch of political mileage, these issues will arise from time to time.

We have the capacity at hand to solve these issues, and I hope that the federal government will maximise those opportunities. I am sure the opposition will always be there, supporting wherever it is practical and reasonable and wherever regions feel vulnerable to external powers and to the power of the federal government. There are regions which feel very isolated in this debate, and I make no secret of this: the people of the Lake Eyre Basin feel particularly isolated and particularly vulnerable after many generations of living there. I ask what right any federal government has to put them out of business. With those few words, I conclude my comments. The coalition does not oppose this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The establishment of the National Environment Protection Council could be the start of a new era in the management of our environment. I must state that I am disappointed that the Western Australian government has expressed views which I thought disappeared years ago. They seem to think they are not part of Australia, for some reason, and that they know better than others; and, of course, they are always right!

PARA.TAB: Some of the issues that the council will address are air quality, marine and estuarine fresh water quality, noise protection, general guidelines for the assessment of site contamination, motor vehicle emissions, and re-use and recycling of materials. All of these issues affect not only eastern Australia but also Western Australia, and of course there are no boundaries to them: they are everyone's problem. The huge cost of rectifying some of these environmental problems requires that the federal government must be involved in determining the best way to resolve the issues at hand and to make certain that the answer is applicable to every state and territory.

I would like to address a couple of areas where the National Environment Protection Council could be very effective. Australia is one of only two countries in the world to allow the dumping of toxic or radioactive waste into the sea. The Tasmanian government and the Australian government allow Pasminco to dump 240,000 tonnes of toxic sludge per year into the sea off Tasmania. Australia is also one of seven wealthy nations currently dumping plastics, metal sludge, lead batteries and other waste in South-East Asia. For example, in the months of September to December 1993, New South Wales exported 63,000 tonnes of lead battery waste to the Philippines. We are exporting our waste, and this is the sort of thing that the new body should be looking at very closely.

In the area of marine pollution, 58 million tonnes of ballast water from foreign ships is discharged annually into our waters. I repeat: 58 million tonnes—a huge amount of water. With this water come all sorts of problems, all types of organisms, such as starfish and—recently—giant worms. These worms are in Port Phillip Bay. I do not think they are in the area of the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), but they could be coming up the Maribyrnong Creek very quickly. These giant, spaghetti-like worms are threatening marine life in Melbourne's Port Phillip Bay. They have also been discovered in Western Australia, potentially jeopardising some of the nation's richest fisheries.

Here we have two completely different areas: one on the east coast and one on the west coast. Of course, Western Australia does not want to get involved in this, but there are also giant worms over there. These 50 centimetre worms, believed to have been introduced from the Mediterranean by foreign ships discharging ballast waters, were detected this week in Cockburn Sound near Perth and scientists warned yesterday they may have spread as far north as the fishing grounds off Carnarvon.

A national study is under way amid fears that these worms may have moved up the eastern seaboard from Port Phillip Bay where there is already a huge colony of these worms, covering an area of 500 square kilometres. This is the sort of thing that this protection council must address. It is a national issue that is becoming bigger and bigger. It is also a perfect example of the need for this body to oversee what is a national problem. If this body is to work, it must have the cooperation of all of the states. That is why I am very disappointed that Western Australia has not agreed to this.
When I was elected in March of 1983—a great year, I can assure you—the first words I uttered in this House were in the form of a question to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Can the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment inform the House of the Government's attitude to using the external powers contained in section 51 (xxix) of the Constitution to protect the world heritage property in South West Tasmania. Further, is the Government's attitude similar to the position of the former Opposition spokesman on the environment and conservation?

Is the Government trying to achieve bipartisan support for the preservation of areas of Australia's natural heritage such as the South West Tasmania wilderness, or is the Government aware of divergence in views on environmental positions?

This is a question that I asked back in 1983 but it is exactly what we are talking about today—the states' rights. My question at that time related of course to the Franklin River and the problems that were being experienced down there. There was bipartisan support for that at that time. The Fraser government had come out and said that it would not build the Franklin Dam. Of course, it was all a bit late for the Fraser government because it lost on that issue in the election campaign. The Tasmanian government at the time did not agree with that statement but we all know what happened: the dam was not built. Even today, as I will demonstrate to you later, there are huge numbers of people travelling down to Tasmania to see not a dam but a free running river. I trust that I will not have to ask that sort of question in the future.

PARA.TAB: Speaking of Tasmania also gives me the opportunity to raise another issue of national importance that is about to take off. I am talking about the restoration of beautiful Lake Pedder. A campaign has already started, and it has the support of many people from all over the world, ranging from Prince Phillip to Dick Smith. They are quite different people but they have supported what is called `pulling the plug on Lake Pedder.' I think this is the first time that this issue has been raised in the House and I intend to campaign very strongly to make certain that Lake Pedder is restored to its former pristine beauty.

Let me give members a little of the history of what happened there. The Tasmanian government began flooding Lake Pedder as part of the Gordon River power development scheme in 1972. This action was taken despite a substantial body of scientific evidence and public opinion that Lake Pedder was an area of significant long-term scientific value. Lake Pedder had been declared a national park in 1955, in recognition of the area's rugged natural beauty and its significant and aesthetic recreational values. There was a huge public outcry at the time of the flooding, with public protest meetings. There was also a petition with over 10,000 signatures and an avalanche of comment in the Tasmanian media.

The Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission investigated a number of alternative schemes which avoided flooding Lake Pedder and an interim report by the Lake Pedder committee of inquiry recommended that the Australian government provide finance to allow a moratorium on further flooding. At that time, even the people of Tasmania were looking for some sort of direction from the Commonwealth government to try to stop the flooding of Lake Pedder. However, we know what happened. It has been flooded. I think everyone now recognises that it was a mistake to flood this beautiful area.

There are studies now that suggest that not only would the hydro-electric power generated as a result of the flooding not be missed but also that there would be a substantial increase in tourism revenue. Tourism spending would increase by an estimated $24 million and about 600 jobs would be created if Lake Pedder were restored to its pre-dam condition.

More significantly, Tasmania has a power glut of about 130 megawatts. Lake Pedder generates only 65 megawatts. The Comalco smelter is at Bell Bay and the talk is that it will close in 1998. If this happens, the excess power being generated in Tasmania could be 300 megawatts, with nowhere for it to go. If that Bass link were connected to the Victorian or the national power grid, there would then be somewhere for it to go; however, that is pie in the sky. That is also an area where the federal government and the new body could be involved to determine whether that would be something that was in the national interest.

It is possible, I believe, to rectify what has happened in Lake Pedder. If this were done, it would be of enormous benefit to the people of Australia and the world. It would be a simple matter to `pull the plug'. I believe there is a valve that cuts off the river flow into Lake Pedder, and using it is all that would be required to stop the lake from being filled. Then it could be drained by removing one small dam.

If we were to restore Lake Pedder, it would demonstrate to the world that we are leaders in environmental restoration. The symbolism of this action would bring a huge benefit to Tasmania. It would bring it by way of tourists; it would bring it by way of training people on environmental restoration. Let us imagine the work that would have to be involved in restoring just where the water line has eroded. It would be something that we could show to the world as a symbol that this nation is prepared to remove a development which is no longer necessary and turn it back to nature.

It is believed that the sands on the bottom of the dam are covered with about two or three millimetres of sediment and they would be revealed by rain, et cetera, in less than five or six years. We may imagine the work that would be created by restoration of the plantings of grasses and other things that were originally around the shore. People would come from all over the world to see this restoration of this huge area.

One has only to look at the momentum that is coming about through this dream that people have had. In today's Australian Financial Review, which is not really well known for backing the environment, there appears quite a good little article written by Peter Roberts. He says:
The contrast between the richness of the Franklin wilderness and the sterility of major hydro developments such as Lake Gordon and Lake Pedder on the upper Gordon River could not be more extreme.

While the 200-metre tall Gordon Dam is a breathtaking engineering feat, the banks of Lakes Gordon and Pedder are scoured by rapid rises and falls in water levels governed by the need to generate electricity.
Promised boating and other recreational booms have not materialised and the dams sit in a silent and eerily empty landscape.

On the other hand, a short walking trail built along the Franklin banks was alive last week with the sounds of rushing water and black cockatoos, and the rich sights of a complex wet rainforest ecosystem. The last snows of winter lay melting.

Tasmania now stands to gain far more in employment and economic terms from eco-tourism than it could ever have achieved through building ever more dams and searching for heavy industries to consume their power.
Last week there were few tourists at the Gordon Dam, while the lodges at places of natural beauty such as Cradle Mountain were booked out.

SPEECH.PARA: I am talking not about something that was written a long time ago, but about something that was written this morning. That is exactly what could come about if the plug is pulled on Lake Pedder and the Pedder 2000 people get their way. I will be doing everything I can to assist them.

PARA.TAB: The restoration of Lake Pedder may be a dream but, while we have the dreams and efforts of such people who are concerned about the environment, with a lot of work and assistance from this government and the state governments, I am sure their dreams will come true in the not too distant future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the previous speaker, the great supporter of the Kennett government of Victoria, the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth)—
—I did not mention it once.

—I cannot understand why you did not. I agree with the honourable member's opening comments on the international pressures that are now being applied to environmental matters around the Australian coastline, the matters of ships' ballast water, oil slicks and the fact that the Commonwealth needs to take a responsible and cooperative attitude on how it handles such international problems. On those matters I agree with the honourable member for Dunkley, which is not often the case.

PARA.TAB: However, on his basic thesis in relation to Lake Pedder, I find it surprising that somebody espousing environmental considerations would suggest that a hydro-power generation operation be removed from the Tasmanian system. Obviously, to any environmentalist, hydro-power is clean, sustainable and environmentally friendly. So the honourable member's suggestion that the Lake Pedder power operation be removed from the Tasmanian power generation grid and probably in the longer term the national grid—when I think it will inevitably connect with the mainland states' power systems—is a very retrograde step.

I would argue, quite vigorously, from environmental points of view, that Lake Pedder and the generation from that hydro installation should be maintained and that the argument that we unplug Lake Pedder does not stand up to any sensible analysis, either economic or environmental. However, I do not doubt we will hear more about this because of the symbolism that the honourable member might hope to gain in putting forward this proposition. There will be some irrational environmentalists who will emerge from the sidewalks to argue their case, as they have done on a number of other environmental issues.

The National Environment Protection Council Bill is a result of initiative in cooperative federalism, which I very much support. The environment is an issue which has attracted the interest of governments of all persuasions at all levels, as the debate between the member for Dunkley and me indicates.

Despite the emergence of the environment on the Australian political agenda the Commonwealth government has no explicit constitutional authority to legislate with respect to environmental matters. In the past the government has sidestepped this complication by legislating under different heads of power, such as the external affairs power, especially in relation to World Heritage listing, and the trade and commerce power. The Commonwealth is also empowered under section 96 of the constitution to make grants to the states on any terms it deems fit, which has also proved to be a means for the Commonwealth to procure the environmental outcomes it wishes.

The new federalism deal, which motivated the special Premiers Conference in Brisbane in October 1990, resolved that there was a need for different levels of government in Australia to formulate a new approach to decision making. Few would disagree in principle with the conclusions of that body when it pointed to a commitment to:

SPEECH.PARA: The better definition of the respective roles of the Commonwealth and the states and territories with regard to environmental policy formation and implementation.

This statement acknowledges the different roles to be played by the different tiers of government. The next step in this process has been the intergovernmental agreement on the environment in May 1992 which agreed to the establishment of a ministerial council empowered to give effect to the national environmental protection measures.

PARA.TAB: These measures are to cover the areas of air, water quality, noise, site contamination—I notice the member for Dunkley mentioned the battery export, and I have some sympathy with that problem—hazardous wastes, motor vehicle emissions and recycling of materials. Many such categories adopted will undoubtedly fall into categories over which the Commonwealth is not constitutionally empowered to legislate. This is the real difficulty that this legislation has.

The establishment of the NEPC provides the Commonwealth with a role in determining national standards for the environment. However, the states retain much of their control. The decisions of the NEPC require a two-thirds majority of the members. The membership is to consist of a minister from each state and one from the Commonwealth who chairs the council. Complementary legislation must be passed by all state governments in order to breathe life into the NEPC.

So far only Western Australia has stated its intention to oppose this development. I agree with the member for Dunkley that it is unfortunate that the Western Australian government has seen fit not to participate in this complementary legislation. Each national environment protection measure will remain a state concern but will, in part, be dictated by whatever agreements the ministerial council has come to. States will be at liberty to pass more stringent standards than those set down by NEPC.

All in all, as a defender of the federal constitutional system, it is pleasing to see the government following a cooperative model in seeking to promote national policy in the environmental area. Clearly some environmental concerns cross over state boundaries and require a coordinated approach. The NEPC is arguably a response to this. Nevertheless, we should perpetually be harking back to the words that came out of the special Premiers Conference on this issue in 1990 when it was said that the aim of the new environmental approach was to better define the respective roles of the different tiers of government.

This does not mean that we should be concentrating power in the hands of the national ministerial council on all environmental matters. It rather means that we must be careful to determine which environmental issues really are those which cross over state borders and thus require coordinated national attention, and which are best attended to by local and state authorities with their more intimate knowledge, expertise and experience in local issues.

It raises the fundamental issue of who controls environmental matters, whether it be the local authority, the local councils, the state government or, de facto, the federal government. Who really sets the standards? In my home state of Victoria it is the EPA that sets standards of environmental pollution and gauges what is acceptable at any particular time. I notice that the EPA changes its standard levels from time to time.

In my view, environmental issues are moving up the political agenda at a federal level. The electorate is now more concerned about environmental matters. Whilst the Commonwealth does not have direct control, this legislation reflects the movement of environmental and other associated matters into the federal political arena and the attempts of the federal government and the opposition to deal with that movement of political awareness.

I now deal with the matters of salinity, water quality, sewage outfalls and coastal management, which reflect this range of control by various authorities. All Australians and all members of this House should be concerned by the gradual encroachment of salinity across dry land in Western Australia, even in southern Victoria and through New South Wales and Queensland. We have very little capacity to control the movement of this dry land salinity as it moves across the landscape, and very careful educational programs, both with farmers and land users, need to be undertaken.

I took an aeroplane trip over western Victoria and certain parts of western Victoria, in parts of the electorate of Corangamite, in areas where people would think that salinity would not be a problem, it was fairly obvious that there was a creeping salinity problem in those farming areas where improved pasture had been the order of the day, but high stocking rates, a removal of natural vegetation and a change in the environment had allowed salinity to creep—and that is the word, `creep'—forward in its encroachment on good farming land. And, if it is happening in western Victoria, let me assure the House that it is happening in very large doses in Western Australia and other more sparsely vegetated parts of Australia. Obviously people have views about the planting of trees to take the pressure off salinity. I think that is one solution. The application of different pasture species and generally revegetating the landscape are two approaches to overcoming the dry land salinity.

The irrigation water table salinity is a matter that concerns every member of this House. The solution to that problem is a little bit more complex. All the irrigation programs around Australia are subject to this increasing salinity problem, both in the river systems and, of course, in the outflow and the build-up in the water table.

The next matter which helps to demonstrate the necessity for this bill is the situation in the Murray-Darling Basin, which covers so much of central Australia. The basin and catchment areas extend over 14 per cent of the Australian continent. This includes 75 per cent of the state of New South Wales as well as parts of Victoria, Queensland and South Australia, with a population of around two million people across these four states. It contributes a third of Australia's rural output, and it also contains about 75 per cent of irrigated land. It is suggested that it produces about $10 billion of primary produce annually, almost $1 billion from cotton. There are about 16,000 kilometres of rivers in the system and about 10 million megalitres are diverted for irrigation, about 20 times the volume of Sydney Harbour.

Those figures indicate the importance of the Murray-Darling Basin and the necessity to get a cooperative approach between the various states and the Commonwealth to handle the problems that I have been alluding to. The difficulty lies in monitoring the salinity levels in that river system and keeping a very watchful eye on the blue-green algae blooms that have emerged in recent times, I would suggest especially in the last two or three years when the river flow has been a lot less because of the drought. The lack of movement in the river will, I think, further increase the blue-green algae and is something that we will need to be very careful about. So it is important that the states cooperate at the federal level. The question always raised, of course, is where does the money come from to ensure that these cooperative regulatory measures, in some cases, and also corrective measures might take place in that particular basin.

Moving to the sewerage systems of Australia in the urban regions, again these have moved up the political scale as a matter of environmental concern. I think Sydney led the way in increasing public consciousness about sewerage systems and ocean outfalls. In my home state of Victoria, the problems that the Sydney sewerage system had were always referred to in any public or private debate, and certainly the bad publicity surrounding that particular system, the inadequacy of the ancient system and the way in which it flowed into the ocean outfalls was an example to the rest of Australia of how not to do it. In Victoria certainly the political debate was raised a few notches.

The Environment Protection Authority in that state changed the criteria for ocean outfalls and in my own electorate of Corangamite the Black Rock sewage outfall for Geelong was very much a part of a major argument as to the quality of the sewage outfall that moved into the Southern Ocean, acceptable in the 1980s but unacceptable in the 1990s and requiring another $30 million of expenditure to improve the quality and refinement of the sewage that moved into the ocean.

Further ocean outfalls along the southern coast at Anglesea, Lorne and Apollo Bay indicate the national significance of maintaining high quality sewage outfalls into the ocean which I think would be reflected in other parts of the Australian coastline. The key question is: should it be a state responsibility or should it be a federal coordinated responsibility to ensure the quality of the environment around the coastlines?

I will just refer to the coastal management issue which has been referred to in this chamber on previous occasions. The really big question in Victoria and I guess around the Australian coastline is: who actually controls and manages the coastline around Australia? Is it historically the caravan park management which controls a section of the coastline? This is the situation in the electorate of Corangamite where more profitable caravan parks generate moneys which help foreshore committees maintain sections of the coastline. Is it a responsibility of local government? Is it a responsibility of the state government to coordinate coastal management or should the federal government provide some broad guidelines as to what should happen around the total Australian coastline?

I commend Mark Birrell, Minister for Conservation and Environment in Victoria, who has instituted a management plan for the coastal areas from Lakes Entrance to Portland. There are various kinds of existing arrangements with foreshore committees, local councils, state governments and so on. At long last there is a coordinated approach to see what would be best for the environment, what would be best in terms of the land ownership and what would be best in the longer term, for example, how we might preserve that wonderful ocean road that moves through the southern part of my electorate which attracts so many tourists over time. That really raises these issues: what should federal governments be doing; what should state governments be doing in terms of a legislative arrangement; and should this legislation in a cooperative way allow local authorities to do what they do best at the local level?

I will just make a comment in relation to the control of forestry operations. This is really the responsibility of states and yet federal legislation, through the export licensing of woodchips, is able to maintain considerable control over forestry operations. Likewise, the implementation of the national heritage listing of forest areas, especially in Tasmania and Victoria, allows the Commonwealth to override the views of state governments and state forestry commissions in terms of how they might operate their forest areas.
Mr Tanner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As the member for Melbourne says, it is a matter of judgment as to which particular grouping might win the day. I do have some difficulties in these areas. Because of one small piece of legislation, the Commonwealth government is able to use the might of its export powers to change forestry systems which have been evaluated, re-evaluated and evaluated yet again by environmental groups and environmental impact studies to win political points. This government and the current minister have been using these powers very much to control forestry operations, particularly in Tasmania and in the south-east forest area. I would hope that this legislation would help to overcome the political heavy-handedness of the present government's attitude to forestry activities in these areas.

—I applaud the government and the state governments that have decided to participate—namely, those other than Western Australia—in the establishment of the National Environment Protection Council under this legislation. I think it is fair to say that it is something that is worthwhile giving a go to but my long-term view on this issue is that the federal government should have constitutional powers to deal with environmental matters. I would certainly support a referendum to amend the constitution to enable the federal government to deal with environmental matters. As the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) has indicated, many if not most of those matters extend beyond state boundaries. Clearly it is yet another area where the ramshackle constitutional structure that we have is now severely out of date.

PARA.TAB: I wish to address one of the main areas relevant to the establishment of the National Environment Protection Council and the particular focus that the legislation has—namely, the development of uniform national standards. That main area is the matter of air pollution and motor vehicle emissions. This is a matter that is of particular concern in my electorate because of the nature of my electorate, but it is also of concern to many electorates across the country. The basic problem we have with vehicle emissions is that roughly 65 to 75 per cent of our total air pollution problem is attributable to emissions from motor vehicles. I will take some time to run through the basic details of the emissions that cause problems.

Firstly, there is the problem of particulates, which are known to exacerbate asthma and a variety of other respiratory complaints and diseases, to cause certain forms of cancer and, ultimately, to contribute to premature death. Compounds such as nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide and ozone can exacerbate emphysema, asthma and bronchitis. Carcinogens such as benzene, toluene and a variety of other compounds can cause cancers such as leukaemia and lymphoma. Roughly 90 per cent of the benzene in the atmosphere comes from motor vehicles. There is no known safe level of exposure to benzene in the air.

Finally, and perhaps most commonly known, is the problem of lead in the atmosphere. Roughly 90 per cent of the lead in the atmosphere also comes from motor vehicle emissions. Lead is known to threaten the intelligence level of young children and has a variety of other effects on such things as the renal, nervous, circulatory and reproductive systems.

That is a very brief snapshot of the types of problems that motor vehicle emissions cause, most obviously, of course, for urban dwellers and particularly for those in inner urban areas. The area that I represent in Melbourne is a classic example of an area that suffers from these problems.

A landmark study was recently released. That United States study, which covered 16 years, is called the `Six Cities Study'—as opposed to `sick cities'. It was reported in the New England Journal of Medicine in December 1993. The study was conducted by eight eminent medical researchers. The study looked at the health effects of air pollution over a long period of time on people living in six different United States cities, each with different levels of air pollution problems.

The study looked comprehensively at 811 people over 16 years. The conclusion that the study reached was that people in the most polluted city, the city with the highest level of particulates in the atmosphere, had a 26 per cent higher risk of premature death than those in the least polluted city. The study demonstrated a clear correlation between the presence of particulates in the atmosphere and the risk of premature death.

The study concluded that for every 10 micrograms of particulates per cubic metre of air, for every increase of 10 micrograms of particles that are smaller than 10 microns, the death rate in the community increases by one per cent. Those statistics are a bit mind numbing because they deal with measures that we are not normally accustomed to, unless we have a scientific background, but I think it is something worth noting. What they are saying is that particulates in the atmosphere, which predominantly come from motor vehicle emissions, cause people to die earlier than they otherwise would.

Recent research in Melbourne has shown that in areas near major freeways such as the south-eastern arterial and even some main roads, the level of particulates in the atmosphere sometimes reaches 60 to 70 micrograms per cubic metre, which is way above the standard of the United States Environmental Protection Agency, which, in turn, according to the six cities study, is itself above the safe level at which particulates are acceptable.

The six cities study in effect showed that the level at which premature deaths can be expected to occur as a result of particulates in the atmosphere is, in fact, significantly below what the US EPA currently defines as a safe level. As a result of this, the United States Lung Association is taking legal proceedings in the United States against the EPA to endeavour to force it to try to tighten up the standard. In fact, the standard is three times higher than the level at which the study found that premature deaths began. As a result of the study, it was estimated that particulate emissions from motor vehicles probably account for somewhere in the vicinity of 60,000 premature deaths per year in the United States.

Clearly, extrapolatory figures of that nature are always vulnerable to some degree of fluctuation. They are an estimate; the figure may not be 60,000. However, the most obvious point is that, even if it is only 30,000 or 20,000, it is still an awful lot of people in the United States dying prematurely as a result of this one particular form of motor vehicle pollution.

The estimate that was made on the same basis for Australia was that we can assume that somewhere around 800 people in Sydney and roughly 400 in Melbourne die prematurely each year as a result of particulate emissions. Again, even if it is not 400 in Melbourne, even if it is only 300, that is still roughly about the number of people who die in industrial accidents in Victoria each year. It is a very serious and significant problem.

Another study that was conducted in Melbourne recently by Dr Michael Abramson of the Monash University Department of Social and Preventative Medicine indicated that, over a period of four years, roughly 20 per cent of asthma attack victims admitted to hospital in Victoria were admitted for attacks that were triggered by air pollution. Air pollution levels that caused asthma attacks accounted for 20 per cent of total asthma attacks in that time.

When the C3 freeway, now called the south-eastern arterial, was built in Victoria in the south-eastern suburbs of Melbourne, no study was done about the likely impact of particulate levels in the atmosphere. As I indicated, we have already got levels way above the safety limits. By the look of it, we are soon to repeat that mistake because of the enthusiasm in many parts of government and the bureaucracy to build the western and southern bypasses and to extend the eastern freeway in Melbourne.
