It is noteworthy that Dr Jonathan Streeton, a respiratory specialist from Melbourne who was commissioned to do a study on the particulates issue with respect to these proposals, had his report ultimately not incorporated in the environment effects statement with respect to those two bypass projects and we can perhaps speculate as to why.

There are other vehicle emission pollutant problems to which we need to give consideration. Obviously, lead is one of them. The nitrogen dioxide levels that are now being tested around areas like the south-eastern arterial in Melbourne are already exceeding the safety limits and, given the likely expansion and usage of that freeway, particularly if the southern bypass goes ahead, we can only expect them to get worse.

Obviously, I have only referred to one particular aspect of the problem of vehicle emissions and that is premature death and health effects, which I think are very clearly established. As well as these things, we need to take into account work absenteeism—which, at its most basic, is a consequence of asthma and other respiratory problems that I referred to—and loss of productivity and property damage, estimated to run into billions of dollars every year as a result of air pollution.

We can ask the question: what is the federal government doing about these things? Certainly the establishment of the National Environment Protection Council is a significant step forward. It is one small step towards gradually converting our horse and buggy constitutional structure into something that is relevant to the end of the 20th century and beyond, but there are a lot more things that need to be done.

The decision last year to set a different price for leaded petrol, so that it is higher than for unleaded petrol—a decision for which the federal government was criticised very severely by many parts of the community, including many backbenchers within its own ranks—has been a significant step forward. I am proud to be part of the government that did that. I supported the initiative and will continue to support it. I applaud the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) for her willingness to take on the very powerful forces in the community on that issue, and to stick with doing it. Ultimately, what we are talking about there is the health, particularly, of young children and their ability to develop their intellectual capacities fully, free of the threat of unduly high levels of lead in their bloodstream as a result of vehicle emissions. That is one major step forward.

However, in other areas we still have vehicle emission standards that are a joke. Our current standards with respect to vehicle emissions from petrol driven vehicles are the same as those established in the United States in 1975. Next year we are going to strengthen them—but only to the level that the United States adopted in the mid-1980s; we will still be well behind the United States—and we will introduce standards with respect to emissions from diesel driven vehicles for the first time.

Japanese truck manufacturers are pressuring the government to accept lower controls than those which now apply in the United States, presumably in order to be able to continue exporting vehicles to Australia which do not comply with United States controls. The Australian vehicle industry, with, I suspect—I have to have this confirmed—support from some of the unions involved, has lobbied the government not to adopt the standards that are now in place in the United States because to do so would increase the cost of manufacturing vehicles in Australia and make our vehicle manufacturing industry less competitive and therefore more vulnerable to overseas competition. That I find extremely disturbing.

I have had a lot to do with the vehicle industry previously, as a trade union official. I well know its difficulties and I have been a strong supporter of retaining and expanding the Australian vehicle manufacturing industry. But I am not an uncritical supporter. I am not blind to the broader issues. If the price we are going to have to pay as a community, to ensure that that industry remains as it is, is for people to be dying prematurely as a result of vehicle emissions from substandard vehicles, that is a price that is too high. There are other ways of our ensuring as a community that the vehicle industry can remain in its current form instead of ultimately shifting the cost onto people with respiratory illnesses and people in the community who are more vulnerable to the consequences of things like particulate pollution.

What this illustrates is that in this country we have a huge blind spot in the public arena on transport issues. In effect, most of the people in public life in this country are obsessed in some form or other with roads, with cars and trucks. We say that public transport is heavily subsidised—$1,000 million a year or whatever it is in Victoria and the like—but we never look at the subsidy to road transport, perhaps because it is not quite as obvious, not being written up as a budget item in state budgets and the like.

Let us look at the pollution costs, which are in the billions; the road trauma costs, which are estimated at around $5 billion a year for Australia; the congestion costs; the health costs; and the land use costs. Let us think of the land, the prime real estate, that is used in places like Melbourne and Sydney for the purposes of freeways and major roads and imagine the value of that land if used for other purposes. It would be enormous. Obviously, there are enormous benefits from road transport, but we insist on ignoring the costs. We do not take a balanced view on the issue and we now have a situation where the road lobby in this country is extremely powerful and as a result people die prematurely.

Like the tobacco lobby, however, the road lobby will not be so powerful for ever and it will not be able to withstand community opinion on issues of this nature. It will be a long, hard battle to overcome problems such as particulate emissions, but it is going to be done. Already we are seeing, in places like the mecca of freeways, Los Angeles, a shift in public opinion and government opinion occurring. Now, for example, we have a project in the southern part of Los Angeles to build a major new rail link from the city to the southern coastal regions.

I was a bit disturbed to hear earlier in this debate the comment of the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent)—a member from the other side whom I have some respect for—when he was referring to vehicle emissions and the National Road Transport Council. His comment was that there are safeguards in this legislation to ensure that we do not have the environment impinging unrealistically in areas with broader implications.

I find this a pretty disturbing view from somebody who, I think, is quite a reasonable member in this place. Is it unrealistic to worry about preventing premature deaths in the community? Is it unrealistic to want asthmatics and other sufferers of respiratory illnesses to be able to lead a vaguely normal life? Too often, people in the community treat the environment as if it is some sort of separate thing, as if it is just another thing to be taken into account on a list of a whole heap of things. The environment is us; the environment is people. It is our standard of living; it is our health. It is the physical assets that we, as a community, have built up, and it is our children. It really is a shorthand term for all of these things. It is not just something to which we pay lip-service, where, as soon as there is a bit of pressure from any particular interest group that happens to have a short-term financial interest, we say, `Yes, we are concerned about the environment'. That is simply not the appropriate way to look at these things.'

I represent the inner city area of Melbourne, where the question of extremely high levels of lead in young children's bloodstreams was first brought to public attention about 10 or 12 years ago. My constituents are tired of having their health sacrificed on the altar of worship of freeways, cars and trucks. What they would like to see, and what I would like to see, is massive re-investment in rail and other forms of public transport, adopting world's best practice emission controls on vehicles. There are plenty of people in this place who are very keen on the notion of world's best practice on a few fronts, but they are very selective in how they apply their enthusiasm, so when it comes to things that relate to people dying, or people suffering serious illness or exacerbation of illnesses, then their concerns for world's best practice tend to slide away a bit.

Finally, we need to adopt a balanced approach to transport. One of the things that we certainly do not see in Victoria is an integrated approach to transport planning. I cannot make a definitive statement, but I would be surprised if we see it anywhere else in this country, with perhaps one or two exceptions. We have two separate authorities in Victoria. One dealing with roads, Vicroads, regards politicians as minor players who, even though they theoretically represent the community, just flit on and off the stage while Vicroads grinds relentlessly on with its 30-year plans to have freeways throughout Melbourne. The other authorities, totally separate from Vicroads, are the public transport bodies. We have no integrated planning relating to the genuine needs of transport users in Melbourne. The end result is that the force with all the power, all the clout and all the financial strength in the community—namely, the roads lobby—wins pretty well every time.

If we have to turn these around, that involves some sort of cost on the community. If it involves, for example, problems for the vehicle manufacturing industry, then that is a separate issue. It is an issue that we have got to address, and it is an issue that we have got to tackle very seriously—but it is a separate issue. My view, in the case of the example of the vehicle industry, would be that we ought not just say, `Forget it, because of the cost that will impose on the vehicle industry; we will let the asthmatics and other respiratory illness sufferers continue to suffer and we will let people die prematurely.' What we should say is, `If solving this problem is going to impose some additional cost on that industry, then we, as a community, have to work out a way to counteract that.'The traditional way is—or has been—tariffs and, obviously, one very simplistic way of doing that would be to jack up the tariff again, or alter the timetable for tariff reduction to take account of it. There are much more sophisticated things we could do. I commend the bill to the Committee. I think this is one very small step towards a genuine national approach on environmental matters, and it is a good step.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This National Environment Protection Council Bill 1994 is indeed a very significant bill. It is an important landmark for the environmental protection of Australia, because it is essentially a commitment by the Commonwealth, the states and the respective territories to work in a cooperative spirit to develop national environment protection measures. The hope is expressed in the second reading speech by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon) that the framework which this bill will put in place will enable a more cooperative national approach to the environment, a better definition of roles, a reduction in the number of disputes, greater certainty for business in the decision making process and ultimately, of course, a better environmental protection arrangement for us all.

PARA.TAB: It is important to note that the Commonwealth has no express powers under the constitution in relation to the environment. For that reason I took particular note of the remarks made by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) in his reference to the need for a referendum to give the Commonwealth overriding powers in that particular area. That, of course, is a battle that has yet to be fought.

There is no doubt that over the last 20 years we have seen the Commonwealth increasingly use its environmental powers, limited though they be. As I said, there are no express powers under the constitution in relation to the environment. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth has sought to use other heads of power, principally under section 51 of the constitution, to achieve particular environmental outcomes. For example, the external affairs power was used to claim sovereignty over the continental shelf; sandmining on Fraser Island has been prevented by the use of the trade and commerce power; and rainforests in Queensland and wilderness in Tasmania were preserved using legislation relying on the external affairs power to implement our international treaty obligations.

This utilisation of the powers under section 51 of the constitution clearly has contrasted with the previous cooperative approach which relied on intergovernmental agreements with the states. One would hope, therefore, that this step today is not necessarily a turning back of the tide, shall we say, to the inevitable onrush of federal intervention but, rather, an acknowledgment by the Commonwealth that in many issues there is a need to establish a framework which involves both the Commonwealth and the states working together.

It is particularly pertinent in that context that it was at a special Premiers Conference in Brisbane, on 30 October 1990, that the question of implementation of a national environmental strategy which would involve both the Commonwealth and the states was first discussed. I would just like to note for the record the resolution that came from that meeting. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to avoid conflicts there is a need for a new approach which recognises the national and/or international aspects of environmental decision making but which also recognises the roles of the States and Territories. Central to this is the better definition of the respective roles of the Commonwealth and the States and Territories with regard to environmental policy formulation and implementation.

In other words, this initiative came from the states. It was an acknowledgment that all levels of government have different roles in environmental protection and management, and that any agreement should outline respective roles and responsibilities accordingly. A formal intergovernmental agreement setting out in broad terms the agreed roles of the various levels of government would provide, and has provided, a mechanism for defining respective interests and responsibilities and for better developing and implementing environmental policy across the nation.

PARA.TAB: Consequently, an intergovernmental agreement on the environment was signed by the Commonwealth, the states, territories and the Local Government Association on 1 May 1992. That agreement provided a useful mechanism for a cooperative national approach and, as I said, a better definition of the roles of governments. It acknowledges the national concern of the Commonwealth in environmental issues while, at the same time, clearly providing the states with a significant part to play in the Commonwealth's international negotiations on the environment. It also recognises the trans-boundary nature of environmental concerns and, therefore, the need for ecologically sustainable development and the importance of sustainable land use.

I think it is worth noting that clause 14 of this bill sets out in detail the measures to be known as national environment protection measures which relate to one or other of the following issues in relation to trans-boundary responsibilities for the environment. It mentions air quality, marine, estuarine and fresh water quality, the protection of amenity in relation to noise, general guidelines for the assessment of site contamination, environment impact associated with hazardous waste, reuse and recycling of used materials, motor vehicle noise and emissions.

I note, sadly, that there is no reference there to revegetation or to the maintenance or improvement of Australian soil. I think those two matters are of enormous importance and, again, can be closely related to the fact that environmental problems do not begin or end simply on the basis of state boundaries. They are national issues, and I would hope that the issues of revegetation and soil are not to be in any sense downgraded in this particular context.

The bill establishes the National Environment Protection Council and I have gone through the history of the events leading up to that. The role of the NEPC will be to develop these national measures and, therefore, it is certainly a significant step forward. A proviso is also made for the NEPMs concerning motor vehicle noise and emissions and this means that the object of the exercise will be to work towards a national environment protection standard and also national environment protection goals.

A national environment protection guideline is defined in clause 6 as a guideline that gives guidance on possible means for achieving desired environmental outcomes across the spectrum. Consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development and to ensure simplicity and effectiveness of administration, the council will be developing these NEPMs through a public consultative process. While no detail is given in the bill as to what that process will involve, nevertheless it is an area which demonstrates the need to involve not only government but also the community and interest groups working together.

I believe one of the most significant aspects of this council is that the council's decisions must be supported by the votes of at least two-thirds of the members, whether they are present or not. The fact that decisions are to be made on a two-thirds majority distinguishes this council from other ministerial councils which tend to work on the unanimity rule wherever possible.

An important part of the process of developing the NEPMs is for the states and the territories to be fully involved and that the process itself should be clearly open to public comment. Some states already have mechanisms in this regard. I should mention Victoria here where there is a process to settling air and water pollution guidelines through the Victorian Environment Protection Authority, the EPA.

Recently the authority released a set of draft recommendations detailing the findings of an extensive review of the state environment protection policy relating to the air environment outlining reductions in levels of lead, sulfur dioxide and ozone below current objectives. This is not the case in some other states and territories but again it demonstrates the fact that, while there is clearly, under the council, significant opportunities for the states to develop unique policies relating to their own problems, nevertheless the purpose of the council is to establish what can best be described as minimum national standards which, hopefully, will be achieved by all.

Under the IGAE the states and the territories have also agreed to introduce complementary legislation which will establish the council in all their respective jurisdictions and enforcement of the NEPMs will be achieved through appropriate mechanisms such as state and Commonwealth environment protection authorities. Under clause 17 of schedule 5, this legislation will establish that situation.

The NEPC will take over some of the functions of the state and territory environmental instrumentalities. However, the implementation of the NEPMs will still be the responsibility of the states and the territories through respective complementary legislation.
The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, in the second reading speech made what I thought was a particularly pertinent point when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The council will be assisted by a statutory committee of Commonwealth and state officials and by a small secretariat staffed by Commonwealth public servants but established as a separate service corporation accountable to the council. It is not proposed to create a substantial new bureaucracy for the development of national environment protection measures.

I noted in this context that this backup arrangement is going to have a grand total of nine public servants. Where they are required to do specific research work they will, of course, draw on the resources of the existing state EPAs. The total costs of this exercise in 1994-95 will be a fairly modest $896,000.

PARA.TAB: I think it is pertinent, however, in this particular context to make a brief reference to the position of Western Australia. Although Western Australia was a signatory to the intergovernmental agreement, the Western Australian government has indicated that it will not be participating in the council at this stage. While this does not invalidate the national scheme, the automatic application of national environmental protection measures in Western Australia will clearly not be guaranteed.

The Western Australian minister for the environment has released a paper outlining his government's reasons for the council not being approved. I think we should address these reasons in some measure. Firstly, according to the Western Australian government, the council overrides the state minister in cabinet and therefore the state parliament will forfeit powers to disallow regulations. Secondly, uniform national standards are impractical, whereas local solutions are required because of regional diversity. Thirdly, the council adds a new layer of administration which will only reduce international competitiveness. Finally, the council will be administering inefficient and duplicate state processes. Maybe that will be the case. We will have to hope that it will not be so.

It is worth noting that the NEPMs, and the council itself, under its charter, will in fact be required to take into account regional variations and that the NEPC will not aim for strict uniformity, but rather for a consistent approach to environmental protection. I would have thought that the Western Australian government's concerns and fears—legitimate or not, as the case may ultimately prove to be—would have been better protected had it been an active participant in the council from the beginning, rather than remaining out at this particular stage.

It has also been claimed by the Western Australian authorities that the council will be administratively inefficient. As I stated, with the council having a secretariat of no more than nine, it is rather difficult to seriously argue that there is going to be some massive duplication of responsibilities or administrative overlays between the Commonwealth and the states. Finally, with regard to the states with higher standards than those set by the NEPC, we should not forget the point I made earlier that the council's role is to set minimum standards and not maximum standards. If states want to go above the standard, that is fair enough. That is entirely a state responsibility and something to be applauded; because, by setting high standards in some states, it is hoped that overall standards will rise.

Establishing a minimum national standard means that those states which are below that standard obviously have to come up to it, and that is an internal disciplinary measure which is very useful in this particular context. Consequently, states which have higher standards will push for comparable national standards to avoid comparative disadvantage. I frankly believe that the major issues which the Western Australian government has claimed as being difficulties in this matter are in fact straw men—straw `persons' might be a more appropriate term to use in this day—and therefore it would have been preferable had it decided to be an active participant.

It is very important to re-emphasise the fact that we in Australia, with this vast continent and a relatively small population located principally on the coastline, must understand the ecology of our environment. Therefore, there is a need to emphasise the harmonisation of national measures rather than to seek uniform national measures; because the conditions in Western Australia ecologically are certainly not the same as on the eastern coastal fringe, any more than they are the same as in the central desert hinterland of Australia.

We therefore recognise—and we accept the opposition in the context of this legislation—that the states will still have considerable autonomy to determine the extent to which they set these standards; provided, as I said, that they reach the necessary minimum. Measures will be needed to implement, differently in each state and territory, the standards which in most cases are applicable to their circumstances. The states are also being given significant independence as to how the NEPMs are implemented at the state level.

The emphasis is therefore on harmonisation and national measures rather than on uniformity. We constantly hear this fear from some of the states about uniformity across the nation. One thing is absolutely clear: in environmental matters, uniformity is not necessarily the way to go. But the maintenance of agreed national standards which set minimums which are more or less obligatory is certainly an indicator of the direction in which Australia needs to develop.

It is worth noting that we have seen similar trends taking place. For example, the German government has introduced wide ranging and stringent waste minimisation and pollution reduction strategies. In a few years it will be impossible to trade with Germany unless goods are, for example, 90 per cent recyclable. To export to countries such as Germany and the United States, which have established very high environmental standards, it is necessary that Australia also have high standards and that it presents a national position. Otherwise, ultimately our capacity to trade internationally is going to be affected in a negative sense.

It is also worth noting in our own environment that ASEAN decided last June that uniform standards are needed across the six participating countries. They have got some distance to go but it demonstrates this awareness internationally of the need to increase environmental standards.

There are a number of major environmental issues which I would like to refer to. Almost all the measures and mechanisms for the enforcement of pollution control in Australia are determined and administered by the states and territories. This results in the danger of companies being able to `forum shop': if they want to pollute they can find one deal in one state which makes it economically more beneficial than in another. It is precisely those sorts of attitudes that we need to change. It is also important to try to regulate our response to environmental law to make it consistent. I have prepared a table which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The table simply compares Australia and New Zealand. There we have a federal system on the one hand, and a unitary system on the other. In the area of air pollution Australia has 58 laws, New Zealand has five; noise pollution 48, New Zealand four; solid waste disposal 78, New Zealand two; toxic and hazardous substances 120 laws in Australia, compared with 16 in New Zealand; and so it goes. It is a very revealing indicator of the quantum of legislation which we have put in place in recent years which makes it difficult to administer and difficult for the private sector to carry through.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I note some of the major environmental issues facing this country. We have water pollution; we have blue-green algae blooms on our major rivers—not just the Murray-Darling but also in south-eastern Australia and even the Hawkesbury River; and the Murray-Darling system is in a critical state. When I was the shadow minister for the environment back in 1983 we tried to identify the problems and, sadly, we are more than conscious that they exist today. In fact, it is claimed that the Murray-Darling Basin will require some 15 billion trees alone to give any reasonable chance of rehabilitation. Therefore, the whole Murray-Darling Basin should be seen as a national project of first priority in the environmental rehabilitation of this country.

We have other issues, such as sewage treatment and discharge, which were referred to by my colleague, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur). We have ground water pollution, which is a growing problem. We have salinity, which, again, is a growing problem, especially in areas of eastern Australia as a result of the heavy rainfall of recent years, areas which are now having exactly the opposite problem with a major drought. Overall in this dry continent we have the problem of water quality, which affects both our rural environment and our metropolitan environment.

Hazardous waste is going to be an intractable issue and, again, is going to require the coordination of laws and regulations between the states and the Commonwealth. We have the growth of recycling which is an important area. In fact, the federal government imposes a 21 per cent sales tax on recycled plastic. The question has to be asked, `Why?' Such a high level of sales tax is a disincentive for people to recycle plastic. These are the changes we would like to see in the system so it can be genuinely said that environmental policies are being activated and carried through the parliamentary process in a way which encourages the community to do the right thing.

We have other areas of recycling, such as building rubble, plastics and newsprint. All of these are very important because recycling has to be sold to the public. Members of the public have to be able to see that they have a role to play as consumers and that they are able to make their contribution to the better environment of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's debate on the National Environment Protection Council Bill 1994 displays the problems that we have, as a Commonwealth parliament, in being able to come to grips with matters that are of national importance. They are matters under the constitution which we, as the national parliament, have some difficulty in legislating about. As has been said earlier in this debate, because of the changes in the way that we view the environment, changes that have occurred over the last 100 years, it has been highlighted that we have had to come to some mechanism that evolves out of what has been given the title—to use the jargon—`cooperative federalism', which allows us to put in place goals that we might be able to achieve.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! Could honourable members please go outside if they wish to talk?

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us this piece of legislation which arises, of course, out of the intergovernmental agreement on the environment which was signed in May 1992. There has been some comment that it has taken four years to get to this stage but I think that, given the evolution of the types of solutions that we have to come up with to get around the constitutional problems with which we are confronted, those four years seem reasonable.

PARA.TAB: Without wishing to perhaps torture the agreement that has been displayed on this piece of legislation across the parliament, one just wonders why we cannot have a mature look at the constitution to make the constitution more contemporary on issues such as the environment and other issues that have developed over the past century. I have often remarked that it is amazing how people wish to protect the constitution, which was developed in the 1890s and developed by the founding fathers. The use of that word `father' is interesting, because it was an all-male group of people who put it together. To that extent, it reflected the society within which the constitution was being put together. I only make that comment because there are obvious changes in society.

As I said, quite coincidentally, on the first piece of legislation I ever spoke on in this Main Committee, we are long past the time where we should look upon the constitution as a mechanism that has hobbled together the six colonies as a federation. We should be seeing that there are responsibilities that we have at a national level. As I say, I do not wish to labour that point in the context of this legislation, because I value some of the contributions that I have been able to listen to from members opposite about some of the difficulties that we had in getting to this stage with this National Environment Protection Council.

For instance, I thought that the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who spoke before me, made some very correct and relevant remarks about the position that we see with the present Western Australian government. He went through some of the concerns that have been put forward by that government, and indicated that there is really no need for that government to have those concerns and that it really does have to look at what is being set up under the umbrella of the National Environment Protection Council. That government has to look at the protections that would be available if it were to be an active member of that council, in relation to the way in which decisions are made—the majority by which those decisions must be made. It must realise that if it is really talking about competitiveness, it should be looking in the real world as we know it at the moment. Recognisable and appropriate environmental standards on which the manufacture of goods or other things are based are very important for our ability to be able to promote goods and to be able to get access to certain markets.

The proposal that we have before us has the undertaking that this will be, as a new administrative unit, a fairly lean unit and that it will take on board the expertise that has been developed over time by different agencies within the states. Recognising that there is the potential for duplication and that there might be the potential for wasteful use of resources, the point is that this outcome is a mechanism that is very important.

Without trying to involve you in the debate, Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that for many years you were a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I think that you were on the committee from 1987 to 1993, when I was also a member. One of the things that was always put to that committee, no matter what reference was before it, was the lack of national standards, and the lack of consistency between the national standards and the various standards that the state and territory governments put in place. That issue is put before the committee regardless of whether it is the land degradation inquiry or the coastal management inquiry. It is even an issue in the inquiry that the committee is presently undertaking into environmental aspects that affect employment.

It is interesting and appropriate to note that issue in the context of some of the criticism that the Western Australian government has made. It is often industry that comes forward to suggest that there is a need for a national standard. As I said, even in the present inquiry, that is one of the things that people in industry say will assist them to be able to develop `green jobs' in a whole range of sectors. In the April 1991 report of the House of Representatives Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled The Injured Coastline—the report of the inquiry on coastal management—we had a recommendation that the national water quality guidelines, based on the assimilative capacity of the receiving waters, be prepared as expeditiously as possible.

At that stage, we had to suggest that perhaps the people in ANZECC, the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, or in Australian water resources should be the ones who develop the national standards. As I understand it, they are the people who—even under the mechanism of the environment protection council—are called upon to be involved in development. However, once those standards are developed, they would have the imprimatur of the council, which of course would have all the states—except, at this stage, Western Australia—involved in it. It is something that would have some substantive strength, even though it would not have any constitutional base and would be a cooperative agreement. As some commentators have suggested, if these things were to be tested, the High Court might have an interesting job in considering the standing of some of the determinations of the council. But that is something that we are going to have to look at in the context of being mature about our ability to discuss constitutional change.

Another problem that we often find in the House of Representatives environment committee inquiries is the lack of basic data about the state of the environment. I know that this is a bit different from the types of standards that this bill talks about the council setting, but if we do not have monitoring standards, we will have great difficulty in being able to see whether we are successful in what we trying to achieve in relation to the way that we treat the environment.

It is interesting to note that, when the minister released the state of the environment reporting framework for Australia earlier this year in June, one of the things that he highlighted about the system is that it will allow for an agreed set of national indicators. In talking about those indicators, the minister made the observation that even those people out in the community who are perhaps not totally economically literate are economically literate enough to know that things such as the CPI are very important monitoring standards.

Why have we not a culture that suggests that environmental standards have the same status? Why is it not that the imagination of the Australian community is captured—so that if we have indications of the standards of air, or indications of the standard of water, that are regularly promoted to the Australian public, we can, over time, assess whether or not we are achieving those outcomes. It is one of the important bases that we have. Why does the Australian public not demand that we assess whether outcomes are positive or whether we are doing negative things that are not indicated through the mechanisms that we have set in place to protect the environment?

It is interesting that, in putting together an agreed set of national indicators, it is likely that we will have reference to the regional differences that affect those indicators. Again, that is one of the things that the Western Australian government seems a bit hung up about at the moment. It believes that, by putting in place the measures under this piece of legislation, those types of regional factors will not be allowed for. That is just a nonsense, and I ask why is it that the other states and territories can find their way clear to be agreeable. They can see that—in terms of what the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) said—the spirit of the agreement was in place.

The schedule to this bill, where the agreement is set out, makes interesting reading as one reads the list of people that were signatories. Some of them have gone onto other roles—unfortunately, in three of the states, at grave consequence to the party to which I belong. But if it was good enough for two out of three of those states to say, I think earlier this year at the COAG meeting, that they were quite happy with this agreement, and if even the government led by Jeffrey `Glib' Kennett, as the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) would say, can see its way clear to be involved—and I say that as a Victorian—then there should be no impediment in the Western Australian government's attitude to the legislation.

I also want to briefly mention that this was one of the first agreements where the role of local government was recognised. In fact, the President of the Australian Local Government Association was a signatory to the agreement. Again, because of the constitutional difficulties in recognising local government, that is an interesting sidelight, but it is important to recognise that, when it comes to the protection of the environment, all spheres of government have a role to play. It is no use spheres of government taking the view that they have competing roles. The honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) talked about the generational effects of the way we treat our environment. It is important that the spheres of government recognise that that is what the protection of the environment is about: it is as much about what we are trying to do in the present as what we are trying to do for future generations. That is of paramount importance.

I believe that we are getting to the stage where we recognise that we have to have a national approach. Environmental problems do not have any hang-up about geopolitical borders that are drawn across maps. We need a national approach to resolve some of the problems that have been mentioned, whether the problems are things such as the algal bloom or motor vehicle emissions. There are similar problems across the nation and they can be addressed in similar ways, recognising that, in properly effecting the solutions, we have to take into account regional conditions.

Whilst I may have sounded like a centralist at the start because I expressed a preference that I would rather see a constitutional solution to these problems, I recognise that, in the administration, and in the ability to achieve outcomes on the ground, we have to take into account regional differences, and that can be achieved by regional administrations. Whether those regional administrations are state and territory governments or local governments at the moment, I do not really mind.

We have to recognise how that can be best achieved. We have to recognise that the national government and the Australian parliament have a distinct role to play in the economic health of this nation. Equally, they have a role to play in protecting the environmental health of the nation.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bradford) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, upon notice, on 30 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many Australian Public Service (APS) officers are surplus to position requirements but are being paid by the Commonwealth.
(2) What is the cost to the Commonwealth of retaining the officers.
(3) Has the APS expanded recently; if so, why have the officers not been absorbed into productive employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The concept of `surplus to position requirements' is not one that is formally recognised under the Public Service Act 1922 or the APS Redeployment and Retirement (Redundancy) Award 1987, and statistics on officers who are surplus to position requirements are not readily available.

Under the Award, where it appears that APS staff are likely to become `excess to a department's requirements', the Secretary of the department must provide details to, and arrange discussions with, the relevant union. When those discussions have been completed, the Secretary may formally advise the affected staff that they are excess to the department's requirements.

There is no central collection point in the Australian Public Service for information on the number of staff who have been formally advised that they are excess to departments' requirements. However, under the 1992 APS Workplace Bargaining Agreement, there is provision for departments to refer to the Central Redeployment Unit (CRU) officers and employees who have been declared excess and who do not wish to pursue voluntary retrenchment.

The Unit's functions have now been assumed by the APS Labour Market Adjustment Branch in the Public Service Commission. As at 9 September 1994 that Branch had 59 referrals of excess officers and employees on hand.

(2) Award arrangements allow for staff who become excess to be retained in employment for seven months (or thirteen months for staff who are over 45 years of age or have more than 20 years' service). The majority of the 59 excess staff are in the thirteen month category.

The fortnightly cost of salary for the 59 excess staff is approximately $71,700. The full salary cost of employing them cannot be estimated because it is not known how many will be redeployed before the expiration of the relevant retention periods.

(3) According to the most recently published statistics, contained in the Department of Finance's Australian Public Service Staffing Statistics Report 1993, the number of staff in the APS declined by 0.8% in the calendar year 1993. Final statistics for the 1993-94 financial year are not yet available.

The Labour Market Adjustment Branch was set up to assist in the redeployment of excess staff across the APS. Together with its predecessor, the CRU, the Branch has assisted in the successful redeployment of 40 excess officers and employees since 1 July 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 31 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: Further to the answer to question No. 713 (Hansard, 22 December 1993, page 4649) relating to the Australian National Line, what information is he prepared to provide on the (a) number and nature of requests for information made of ANL by the Commonwealth Task Force on Asset Sales and (b) number of task force officers who were located in ANL's offices for more than one day.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) Information in respect of the matters referred to in the honourable member's question is not readily available. It would be a lengthy task to assemble the information and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of money and effort which would be involved.

(b) None. During the recently completed due diligence process officers of the Task Force, along with their consultants and officers of the Department of Transport, attended presentations by, and meetings with, ANL management, which in the case of some of the presentations extended across a number of days. ANL also made self contained office space (with phones, and tables and chairs) available to the same parties, but this was only used on an ad hoc and intermittent basis, before or after meetings or presentations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Taxation Office: Casselden Place Child-care Centre

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What sum has been spent on the child care centre at the Casselden Place Branch of the Australian Taxation Office in Melbourne.
(2) Who is able to use the facility.
(3) How many persons are able to use the facility.
(4) Are there any cost recovery mechanisms in relation to the use of the facility; if so, what are they.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) As one of the partners in the Casselden Place Child Care Centre, the Australian Taxation Office has spent $311,940 to acquire priority of access to 20 of the 60 child care places in the centre for a period of at least 10 years.
This means that the Australian Taxation Office has a guaranteed right to use these 20 places for its staff for this period of time. It works out at approximately $1,600 per place per year.

The partners in the Casselden Place Child Care Centre are the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Human Services and Health, the Bureau of Meteorology, the Department of Administrative Services, Telstra Corporation (Telecom Australia), the Australian Postal Corporation, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Australian Industrial Registry and the Australian Electoral Commission.
(2) The facility is for the use of children of staff employed by the partners.
The operating guidelines agreed by the partners allows for temporarily underutilised places to be made available to other employers and to community users.
(3) As mentioned above, the Centre can accommodate 60 children. As many places are filled on a part time basis, the number of employees able to use the centre is more than 60.
(4) Yes.
All parents pay fees to the Centre. Fees are currently $145 per week for children under three years of age and $140 for children aged three to five years of age.
Under the terms of the operating guidelines, partners are able to recover costs from other employers accessing underutilised places.
